nodes.bodyText:
I used getName with the whole package to be consistent with TraceEvents which do the same.
I prefer being consistent over saving the length of the package in this specific event but if you prefer otherwise it's fine for me to change it.
New event types use plain string instead of class full names.

@evacchi @ricardozanini
Here we are using event type to decide if accept of skip the message. Do we agree in general?
That's the model we've decided to follow. But I think won't hurt adding an or condition to check for the event Source as well.

@danielezonca I did it this way because, as Ricardo said, it's the current way it works.
@ricardozanini I assumed that any source can send events to trigger the executions as long as they're formatted correctly. If we want to filter by source we must discuss a logic to distinguish valid sources from invalid ones. Are there already some conventions about this?

Sources are URI attribute, so I think we can start from there. But FWIW, I believe it's better to just open a follow up JIRA to filter by sources and have some discussions around it and how we are going to implement.
From the Knative eventing perspective, we can always use filters to get these events into our platform, so we can cover some use cases until there.

IMO the subject should be the one received in the request event (if any). The subject can be understood as a correlation key and is usually generated by the producer.
Subjects are attributes commonly used to create subscriptions or correlate multiple events.
The new version behaves exactly as @ruromero described about event subjects 👍
What about at least log the error?
What about directly inject DecisionModels instead of Application?
Good idea. Done 👍
Same as above
Good idea. Done 👍
Why Optional<CloudEvent>? After the evaluation we should be sure to emit the event

At this point the response CloudEvent should be built always except for unexpected errors. In this case, with the same logic described in the first part of this comment, the CloudEventUtils::build method would log the message. Shall we add a dedicated log here?

We should not lose messages especially after processing it. What about a log at least?
Btw it should be nice to ack the request only if we are able to process it (probably this change requires a different PR). Wdyt?

What about a log at least

The CloudEventUtils::encode method already logs an error if it can't encode the data. Should we double log in case the logic in that class is changed?
